Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = e^{i\\omega t}\\) representing oscillatory behavior with angular frequency \\(\\omega\\). We examine the scenario where we apply a Fourier transform \\(F\\) to \\(z(t)\\), thereby transforming the function into the frequency domain.

If an alteration is made post-Fourier transform, specifically an amplitude modulation in the frequency domain, will the inverse Fourier transform still yield the original function \\(z(t)\\)?
Explanation: Amplitude modulation or any other alteration in the frequency domain fundamentally changes the spectral characteristics of the signal. Consequently, the inverse Fourier transform will reflect these modifications, resulting in a distortion of the original time-domain signal \\(z(t)\\).
